story:
*If you are unaware of what a longboard skateboard is, please click here*

About Us

We are Charlie and Chris, college students hailing from East Lansing, Michigan. Charlie is an Economics major and Chris is a Business Administration major. Both of us have been avid longboarders since middle school and know everything there is to know about it. We have known each other since we were young lads and are both very like-minded individuals with complementary skill sets.

Our lifelong dream is to own our own small business, and what better way to accomplish that dream than to combine it with something we are very passionate about?

Growing up with longboards we have learned a lot not only about the sport, but the industry. Our idea is to start our own longboard company so that we can put our knowledge and expertise to use, and spread the sensation sweeping the nation.

One thing we both despise about the longboard industry is the costliness of the sport, to get a high quality board you usually need upwards of $250. This struck us as ridiculous, so we checked into it, and it turns out we can produce our own boards with the same quality for up to $100 less than that of the big name brands. Our mission is  to provide top notch longboards on an affordable budget.

To give our product more of a niche, all of our boards will portray unique graphics designed by local, up and coming artists. Every artist that contributes will be compensated per design, and given special credit on our site as promotion. For example, we plan to have an "artisit bio" page, in which information on each specific artist will be displayed including a picture. Our site is still under construction but feel free to check it out at goo.gl/TSmMvi

This is a sample sketch done by one of our artists, Alex B.

Goals

Our initial target audience is college students, with a focus on Michigan State University, where we go to school. Longboarding is very popular here and is continuously growing as a quick and easy way of getting to class. The local market is very large and we hope to capitalize on this influx of customers. In essence, our business aims to spread the fascinating sport of longboarding while showcasing amazing artwork done by the customer's very own peers.

We plan to utilize internet sales only at first, while trying to maintain a strong local presence. We have met with other local business leaders about joint marketing in hopes of building local recognition before branching outwards to other parts of the state, and eventually the country.

Being based in the college town of East Lansing, MI we feel as though we are in a great location to start a skate company. The high volume of students provides a large market of young people in need of not only sport and recreation, but transportation as well. Longboarding is quickly becoming a favored mode of transportation on college campuses, mainly for this reason; any one can do it. People of all shapes and sizes, all genders, regardless of athleticism and coordination can pick it up with a little practice.

 

 This is our prototype longboard deck, designed by one of our artists, Connor M.

 These are the different deck designs we will be using for our boards.

 

Where Your Money Is Going

We both can barely contain our excitement to get this thing moving, but we need something from you first!

 

Around $5,000 of the $7000 we are trying to raise will go directly to our initial order of parts from our supplier including wheels, bearings, bushings, trucks, decks etc. and the cost of production. The remaining $2,000 will go towards paying artists, and printing their designs onto our decks. This is just about the bare minimum, any more is greatly appreciated as it will allow us to grow more quickly.

 

If we do not raise the necessary funds,we will simply try again. Maybe take out a loan, maybe try a different crowd funding site, or maybe even have a big garage sale! The point is, this is truly our dream and we will stop at nothing until we accomplish it.

 

We have taken this idea as far as we can by ourselves, and are now asking for your help to make our dream a reality! We have gotten the necessary tax forms, registered with the state and lined up suppliers. All we need now is funding, and we will be ready to start a new, highly profitable, chapter to our lives. Our futures lie in your hands!

If you cannot afford the $10 minimum but still want to contribute, we will make sure to send you a great thank you email! Anything helps! Share with your friends and family! 


*All contributors will receive a link to an exclusive blog to follow our progress*

story:
THE AMAZING STORY OF BOX 13:

In 2008, eight artists went searching for a home in which to make and exhibit cutting-edge contemporary art. They stumbled across an abandoned sewing machine factory showroom, fell in love with this crazy beautiful space, and thus, BOX 13 was born.  Now, after six years of world-class programming in this quirky brick building in the East End, we’re facing new challenges and embracing new opportunities!  But we need to get from ‘HERE’ to ‘THERE’ and we need $15,000 now to help us do it.

When it started, nobody could have foreseen the massive impact that BOX 13 would have on Houston’s cultural life, on the careers of the artists it has supported and presented, or on Houston’s artistic community. It’s become the ‘multi-disciplinary art center that could’, a wildly adventurous space run by its resident artists (without a staff!!!!) and hosting some of the edgiest exhibits in the city.

NONE of this could this have happened without you. In 2013 we saw the need for increased support to help maintain our home at 6700 Harrisburg, and Indiegogo supporters (sound familiar?) helped us to succeed in raising over $9,000 (which is amazing!!!) but costs have gone up and our funding needs have gone up with them.  The fact is that without your support, BOX 13 will be forced to relocate or significantly restrict its mission. But. . .but. . . but . . .(and this is the important part) with your help, we are confident that we can meet - even maybe exceed - our goals again.

In just six years, we have exhibited amazing work from hundreds of local Houston artists, not to mention others from the US and around the world (remember that show we presented from the Netherlands? What about the one from London?)  We’ve shown established artists, emerging artists and piles and piles of extraordinary work in our four exhibition spaces, and collaborated with some of the best arts organizations in Houston. 

We’ve mounted as many of four independent shows a month (which with a little math works out to the work of more than 350 artists!!!) The medium doesn’t matter as much as the idea.  BOX 13 has shown painting, installation, video, sound, sculpture, photography, ceramics, printmaking, drawing, fibers, and performance.

Here’s just a short list of some of the collaborative efforts BOX 13 has undertaken with other arts organizations:

  • Hosted independent shows as part of the Texas Biennial
  • Participated in the East End’s renaissance, including The Light Rail Art Trail’s site-specific art installations
  • Partnered with DiverseWorks and Barrio Dogs to creatively address Houston’s animal over-population crisis
  • Hosted separate shows of painting, photography and sculpture by advanced students at the University of Houston
  • Hosted performances for the Second Lone Star Performance Explosion, Texas’only performance art biennial
  • Showed members' work at Art League Houston
  • Exhibited members' work at Texas State University
  • Repeatedly served as a participating space for FotoFest’s photography biennial

With your support, the artists who call BOX 13 home will be able to continue presenting Houston with groundbreaking, challenging and exciting work from home and afar.

BOX 13 is a cultural hub.  It is unique and vitally important to Houston’s art community. Together we have transformed an old sewing factory into a humming incubator of art and design. And we need you to keep it humming with us.

It’s been an amazing 6 years, we hope that it is the start of many more to come!

Thank you for your support!


Glide by Jonathan Leach

Super Awesome Tee Shirt! (Poster has the same design)

Emily Link, Undead Digits

Kristy Peet, Introvert (balloons), Archival Inkjet Print, 15x12", Edition of 10.

David McClain, Christmas at Doyt and Marlene's. Archival Inkjet Print, 11x14",  Edition of 10.

Nick Vaughan and Jake Margolin, Texas: Double Cowboy (Pink), 2014, Silkscreen on paper, 15"x17", Edition of 30

Masumi Kataoka, Untitled, 2013, Animal intestine, Nylon, sterling silver, Glue, Stainless steel. 7x3.5x2 inches.


Miao Jiaxin’s Brooklyn B&B - You can choose to participate in his art project or simply use it as a regular B&B room.  More info about the art project can be found at: https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.15677...


Tudor Mitroi, Untitled Blue Map, 2014, casein, acrylic, graphite/wood, 11 1/4 x 25 1/2

Garland Fielder, Offset Linear Construction (Black & White Version)
acrylic on Spanish Cedar & hardware, 48 x 48 inches, 2010

detail of Offset Linear Construction (Black & White Version)



Sample for custom sweatered deer head by Elaine Bradford

story:
I started making jewelry at the end of 2011.  I sat down with a friend to learn how to wire-wrap stones and crystals.  This atypical, free flow art of bending wire changed my perception on life.  At the beginning of this year I took several metalsmithing classes and fell in love with the manipulation of metals.

As of right now, I have access to an open studio where I took metalsmithing classes.  The problem is I am only allowed four hours, once a week to do what I love and it really, truly is not enough time to do work.

This is where I need YOU!

Help Wanted!

I am hoping to raise $2000 to purchase equipment.  Contributions will go towards things like stainless steel table, soldering equipment and air filtration system, files, a flex-shaft drill, gravers, hammers, gauges, an anvil and other various items needed for finishing pieces.

Help fund my future studio and become part of my creative process!

What if I don’t reach my goal? 

That’s impossible because every contribution, no matter how great or small, helps me achieve my dream.  Every contribution means I am one step closer to that glorious set of files that makes those metals as smooth as a baby’s bottom.

Can't make monetary contributions?

That's okay!  Any help, in any way shape or form is truly appreciated! 

Social networking has allowed information to travel at the speed of light.  So Tumble it, Tweet it, Share it or simply tell somebody about it from your best friend to your great grandma Betty Sue.

 

Email me at tlmattia87@gmail.com to discuss ring sizing.

story:
Project: In Relation

In Relation: A Project on Sharing Stories of Women Through Art

Collaborators: Lindsay Carron and Courtney Belle Branch


What do you love about being a woman?  This is one of the five questions Courtney Branch and I ask to women all over the world in our project called “In Relation”.  ”In Relation” is an initiative that utilizes portraiture and art to cultivate relationships with women across cultures and convey their stories for the purpose of empowering and uplifting.  We believe that every woman’s story matters.  We wish to create art that speaks to the human condition and acts as a conduit for communication and connection.  As we share the portraits and narratives across borders, these women’s stories are able to have an impact now and in the future.

The portraits and the stories are available for purchase in the form of  10x12” fine art prints signed by the artists.  The sale of the portrait acts as a donation to the organization that serves the particular woman depicted in the artwork.  

New Beginnings Rehabilitation Center: Vicente Guerrero, Baja California, Mexico

January, 2014

Courtney and I worked for two weeks with women at a rehabilitation center called New Beginnings in Vicente Guerrero, Baja California, Mexico.  We spent time with these women, learning the stories about domestic violence, sexual abuse, slave trade, drug and alcohol abuse, and physical assault.  We depicted the women in hand-drawn portraits and gifted these to them.  We painted murals of the portraits on the center’s walls.  We came back to the United States with prints of the portraits and the women’s stories to share, in hopes that they can inspire other women and men around the world.

Here are the heroes we got to know at New Beginnings:


Karla: Age 21, Children: Stacy, 3 months old


Maria Magdalena: Age 30, Children: Neli Guadalupe, 5 years old, Rodolfo Manuel, 14 years old


Silvia: Age 24, Children: Abram, 2 years old, Ramiro, 4 years old


Jaira: Age 24, Children: Esmerelda, 4 years old, Joselin, 7 years old, Daleyssa, 8 months old


Maria Soledad: Age 25, Children: Esmerelda, 9 years old, Aurora, 2.5 years old, Misael, 6 months old


Elvia: Age 34, Children: Luz Amayrani, 15 years old, Jesus Daniel, 8 years old

What We Need & What You Get


  This Campaign is to continue supporting the women and work from our recent project at New Beginnings.  The money raised will support the artists as they develop the In Relation project and 25% of every purchase will go directly to New Beginnings Rehabilitation Center.  

  Because this week is all about honoring women and we are launching our print run, we  are offering discounted prices on the prints for the two weeks of our campaign! 


Media

Here are a few places you can see our work.

http://www.cartwheelart.com/2013/12/16/empowering-through-art-in-vicente-guerrero-mexico/

http://www.onebillionrising.org/9115/relation-artist-lindsay-carron-shares-rising/

http://lindsaycarron.com/2013/11/28/vicente-guerrero-empowering-through-art/

http://www.newbeginningsbaja.

http://courtneybellebranchart.blogspot.com/


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in contributing in other ways please reach out to Lindsay Carron or Courtney Belle Branch at the emails below.

lindsay.carron@gmail.com

court.branch@gmail.com

or visit the New Beginnings website at:

http://www.newbeginningsbaja.org/

story:
Who We Are
Since 2009, Armchair/Shotgun has been bringing new stories, poems, art, and interviews to audiences in New York, North Carolina, Chicago, and Cambridge. We're proud of our commitment to a high-quality print product and of our process that keeps our submitters' names a secret until we've selected their pieces--to ensure we're choosing only the best writing unprejudiced by famous names or qualifications.

Why We Are Crowdfunding
 
We have big plans, including nonprofit status, subscriptions, and expanding to new cities, but we need your help to get there! Help us maintain the same high standards you love as we print Issue 5 and prepare for a whole new world of legitimacy.

What Your Support Pays For
  • Printing Issue 5, featuring the stories and poetry of Woodlief Thomas, Devin Kelly, Rob Adams McKean, Patricia Murphy, Juan Ramirez and more, plus brilliant color to show off the art of Avery McCarthy and Dan-ah Kim
  • Shipping costs to help us reach new audiences
  • Fees as we transition to nonprofit status for long-term fiscal health

story:
Project Description

We are a group of artists that have been dancing together for years. We love celebrating our love of nature through collaborative multi media projects.

“The Mother Reborn” project is the first video we are creating together.  It is intended to be our launching pad to making many more “Dancing in nature” videos.  It will show our artistic approach and esthetic orientation and will help us raise funds for our non profit organization.

What We Already Have 

We have been working on this adventure now for more then a year. We have created the costumes and the head dresses  for the Raven; the Moss, the Owl and are currently working on the Mother Tree. 

We have also completed our Camouflaged ground cover . We have the location and the Story Board for the video.  collectively we spent at least $2000.-  on this already.

We have filmed the crystal bowl goddess inviting the participants to the location. In other words we have already begun filming. We have the first chapter and need your help to complete the rest of the story. 

What We Need

So far everyone on our team has been donating their time and expenses . We are hoping to be able to pay some of our collaborators for their travel expenses, and we are determined to complete this adventure with whatever financial support we get. You help will allow us to:

  • Pay our photographer’s expenses
  • Buy a hard drive
  • Rent Editing equipment
  • Finalize costumes & headdresses for the Tree and Acorn

The Impact

How do we measure the impact of being inspired by beauty?

How do we mesure being moved by witnesing others achieve creative and esthetic excellence ? 

So many people today love dancing and love nature. We are hoping to impact young people by demonstrating the spirit of creativity and our collective connectivity.We hope to egnite the spirit of co creation with the artists and nature lovers of the world. 

The help we recieve from crowdfunding allows this video to come to life. We all come from The Mother and we hope to make this video to honor her.

Project Description
We are a group of artists that have been dancing together for years. We love celebrating our love of nature through collaborative multi media projects.
“The Mother Reborn” project is the first video we are creating together.  It is intended to be our launching pad to making many more “Dancing in nature” videos.  It will show our artistic approach and esthetic orientation and will help us raise funds for our non profit organization.


What We Already Have 
We have been working on this adventure now for more then a year. We have created the costumes and the head dresses  for the Raven; the Moss, the Owl and are currently working on the Mother Tree. 
We have also completed our Camouflaged ground cover . We have the location and the Story Board for the video.  collectively we spent at least $2000.-  on this already.
We have filmed the crystal bowl goddess inviting the participants to the location. In other words we have already begun filming. We have the first chapter and need your help to complete the rest of the story. 


What We Need
So far everyone on our team has been donating their time and expenses . We are hoping to be able to pay some of our collaborators for their travel expenses, and we are determined to complete this adventure with whatever financial support we get. You help will allow us to:

Pay our photographer’s expenses
Buy a hard drive
Rent Editing equipment
Finalize costumes & headdresses for the Tree and Acorn

The Impact


How do we measure the impact of being inspired by beauty?
How do we mesure being moved by witnesing others achieve creative and esthetic excellence ? 
So many people today love dancing and love nature. We are hoping to impact young people by demonstrating the spirit of creativity and our collective connectivity.We hope to egnite the spirit of co creation with the artists and nature lovers of the world. 
The help we recieve from crowdfunding allows this video to come to life. We all come from The Mother and we hope to make this video to honor her.

story:
Hullo Everyone

We are Out of Site, Chicago and we have been creating public performance in Wicker Park and Bucktown for three years. We want to bring culture to everyone and the idea was to activate abandoned spaces in the neighborhood on a Friday night from 5pm to 7pm as people come home from work at the weekends. If you've spotted an opera singer singing in the shower at Six Corners or a dance company performing in the Polish Triangle that is us. We bring culture to everyone curating a rich and diverse program of dance, theater and performance art!

Our Wish List for 2013

We are looking to provide more financial assistance to our international artist Ieke Trinks who needs more money for materials for her performance. Part of our mission is to provide a sustainable economy for everyone working on the project from the stewards, editors and volunteers so if we reach our goal of 5000 we will be paying people for their hard work.

If you support our campaign over $20 you will receive a Do you believe in wonder? t-shirt, a dvd of last years short films, a OoS 2013 poster and if you donate over a $500 you will receive a limited edition print of a photo from a performance of your choice printed on archival paper at the best quality printer in town.

If we don't reach our goal the money will go to funding the International Artist and paying for documentation of the project but we hope you will support Chicago Performance Art Community and help us reach our goal!

OoS 2013

OoS 2013 brings exciting innovative performance practice to everyone, we hope you can support this exciting project and stay tuned with us on Facebook and come along and enjoy the performances. We really want to bring surprise to your everyday life and create wonder in the world!

story:
Short Summary

Hi,

My name is Nicole Skipper. I am currently a student at Montgomery County Community College (MCCC). I graduate in May and move on to my dream school, Moore College of art and design. I have worked very hard to get back into school after being out in the work force for quite some time. I am very proud of all the things I have learned from MCCC, and can not wait to see what Moore has to offer. 

 I am trying to raise money for admission fees, art supplies, and tuition. I have always dreamed of going to art school and to get into the school that I wanted makes it all the more exciting.

I have chosen the major of Art Education. I love to work with children and of course I love art. Having the chance to go after my dream of being an art teacher is so exciting, I can't stop going over potential art lessons in my head! I want to inspire my class to create everything and anything; if its in your head lets make some art!  Art good or bad we can learn from it.


What We Need & What You Get

The funds that I receive will go to art supplies, admission fees, and tuition. The more money you donate you will receive custom art work from yours truley. If i do not reach my goal all funds received will go still go to  tuition, and art supplies.

The Impact

the Earth without "Art" is just "Eh".

- Unknown

I want to inspire the young minds of children to achieve all of their artistic dreams. If there is something that you wanna do, lets do it! What ever material you want to work with, plaster, pencil, pen, marker, etc. lets make it happen and make you great. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

.

story:
Today we are asking our worldwide communities to support “A Bus for the Gagá la Ceja” campaign by following very simple steps. We are raising money to buy a school bus/guagua for organizers of Gagá La Ceja to use for cultural ceremonies during holy week and beyond"

This year we want to invite you to build together with our collective TINGO: Grita Fuerte an international bridge of love in the sugar field in the Dominican Republic, La Romana by generating $15,000. This money will be used to buy a bus that will be used to make possible a yearly Ancestor’s Ceremony in the Sugar Field where a pure manifestation of unity between Haitian and Dominican brothers and sisters take place. We believe in the importance of building sustainability and this bus will allow the organizers of this ceremony in the Dominican Republic generate money throughout the year that is needed to sustain this ceremony yearly.

How? This bus will have three uses:

1)  Transport El Gaga from town to town every year for the ceremony.

2)  Public transportation to generate income throughout the year so the organizers can have the ceremony

3)  To take the children to cultural events for recreational purposes  and to school in the town

We know you are by our side and will bring unstoppable happiness to this Sugar Field in La Romana.

The Story that brought us to Indiegogo

When TINGO: Grita Fuerte’s Co-founder Nathalie Tejada visited her country the Dominican Republic after 8 years of having migrated to the United States, New York, she was invited to El Gagá de la Ceja by her friends. During her participation she saw the abundance of love, smile and happiness in this celebration but she also became present to many of the limitations that can stop such celebration from happening. As a result, when she came back to New York with the help of other members, organizers, and artist, started sending monetary support but the need prevailed.  To find sustainable solutions, today we are choosing Indiegogo to register all of you into the possibility to transform this town by opening up unlimited possibilities for growth. 

What is a Gagá??

Gagá de la Ceja is a spiritual/religious ceremony that takes place in a Batey in the Dominican Republic. Batey (in these times) is what we call the villages that are in the sugarcane fields. These villages are populated mainly by the people who work in the sugarcane fields, most of them are Haitian citizens and Dominicans of Haitian descent. The families that live in the Batey receive their income from working in this factories called, sugarcane fields. The level of poverty in the Batey is high due to the lack of opportunities, discriminatory policies, not a having legal status, working conditions, among other factors.


Why is this Bus/Guagua important?

This bus is important because we believe it is important to you too. This is a bridge that we are all building together. You and us, us and you, all of us together because it is possible. This bus will serve as vehicle to keep manifesting our Ancestral Traditions. It will give our children an opportunity to dream, the power to a town to carry their celebration and generate sustainability.

·  To maintain our culture for the present-generations

·  To Celebrate love

·  To manifest Unity

·  To cultivate traditions and spirituality

What we want?

Bus Price: $15,000
Total = $ 15,000

With this amount, we can definitely make this vision a reality, and we keep this celebration alive in the sugar field in La Romana!! However, we hope to raise more than our goal, in which case we will use the money to invite Haitians and Dominican artists to create a mural of unity on the bus.

What We Have

We have the Bateyes ready to celebrate, we have the musical instruments, the musicians, Los Mayores, The Queens and all the desire to continue engaging the people from the one Island to celebrate. 

Collaboration!

We are asking for people to get on the Guagua for Gagá de la Ceja by:

·  Donating through the Indiegogo Campaign

·  Promoting the campaign by spreading the word with friends and family

·  Talk about it on Facebook, Blog, Instagram,Tweet it all day, Email, and other social networks

·  Organizing an event

·  Donating your talents/skills

·  Committing to the selling of T-Shirts

·  Spreading the word with friends and family

·  Bring New Ideas to raise the funds and take it on

LETS MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

ORGANIZE FUNDRAISERS!

Super excited to have you all on our side! We also want to encourage all of you to work with us generating this $$$ by organizing fundraisers. We are located in the NY area and we are open to go and talk about the project and also support you by providing any material. We also want our global community to be part of this.  Each of us can put a brick to build this together! 

Contact us at email: tingogritafuerte@gmail.com
Blog: http://tingogritafuerte.wordpress.com/

Highlights from 2012-2013

THANK YOU!

TINGO: Grita Fuerte's supporters. We are grateful to have our communities donating your time, talent, money and committed always to bring every possibility to life. Thank you! We appreciate each of you. Between 2012-2013, we raised $ 1,500 that was used to pay for bus rental.

Special thanks to Kalunga Neg Mawon, Camaradas, Ocha Records, Dj Sabine, Reynaldo Pantaleon, Kaila Paulino, Nina Paulino, Cynthia La Cruz, Hache ST, Dominican Women's Development Center, Bodoma Garifuna Culture Band, Realengo Studio, Artistas Curanderas-The Healing Artist Cooperative, Divine Designs for the (god'is) in you, Momma's Hip Hop Kitchent, Black Women Blueprint, KumbaCare, Joselina Fay, Lucia Roxana Cruz-castro and every person that had supported this vision since day one.

About TINGO: Grita Fuerte

TINGÓ: Grita Fuerte is a cultural, spiritual and political organization for Afro womyn. Its purpose is to create a platform for Afro Womyn to heal through embracing our culture, traditions and rituals. Its belief is that going back to the roots of our cultures, we can transform our life. To learn more about us, click here: TINGO

*Your donation is not tax deductible. We want to reiterate that this is not a charitable donation, but a contribution to hold this Ancestral Ceremony alive. We are not a charitable institution, and 100% of the funds are going towards el Gagá de la Ceja and to help TINGO grow and strengthen our cause.

PS:

If you want to send a donation via check, please make the check payable to:

TINGO: Grita Fuerte

Memo: La Guagua

Mail to: 3340 Bailey Ave #8F, Bronx, NY 10463

Paypal:

tingogritafuerte@gmail.com

Thanks for checking out the page. The campaign will run for 60 days.

We got this mi Gente!

story:
Hello All!

My name is Jana Renee. 

Last year I was working three jobs: as a fine dining waitress, a salesgirl at a vintage and reclaimed clothing store as well as a part of a mural collaborative in a local jazz bar/restaurant called the Beat Hotel. This was an amazing time for me! Unfortunately the lack of sleep lowered my immune system and I contracted acute tonsillitis and mononucleosis. The doctors informed me that the recovery for these illnesses required complete rest, as the organs in my body were swollen and overexertion was potentially fatal! 
I am a very high energy happy go lucky gal on the usual, although the main symptoms of recovery are severe fatigue. Until now, I have been doing amazingly! selling my art, but realized that working as hard as I have been to keep up has been slowing down my recovery. 

I am very excited about the upcoming summer season as it holds for me two local Boston mural projects as well as more portrait painting commissions! 

I am coming to a point in my career where my selling prices are raising. So before that goes about, I want to put my work out there at affordable prices.

Anyone who donates $50+ to my cause will receive a pencil portrait of one sitter whether animal or human, and anyone who donates $200+ gets a small oil portrait! So you aren't just sponsoring me as an artist, you are buying fine art as well that has the potential of accruing value as I continue to pursue my art career! 

Thank you for taking the time to read about me! I look forward to hearing from all of you, even if you are unable to help. 

Here is a link to my facebook album where I have some of my work posted

https://www.facebook.com/thejanarenee/media_set?set=a.4013010973411.2133081.1525380120&type=3

...and here is a link to my YouTube if you would like me to serenade you in the comfort of your cozy home.

http://www.youtube.com/user/thejanarenee

story:
NEW STRETCH GOAL OF $50,000!!!

As Operation Protective Edge expands in Gaza, SO DOES THE NEED! We have decided to expand our project so that we can continue to provide necessary items that our BRAVE soldiers so desperately need. Just this morning we were able to provide an 300 Elite troops with  underwear, towels, socks, tshirts and drinks, shampoo, toothbrushes and toothpaste. The troops were so grateful to all of our backers. PLEASE SHOW YOUR SUPPORT!


Hi! We're Shira Frimer, Josh Hasten & Sarit Rapp, citizens of Israel currently living under Hamas rocket fire.  Several times a day a blaring siren sends us running for cover. We have 60 seconds. 60 seconds before we hear "BOOM" overhead. But we are not afraid because that explosing means that the Iron Dome system has shot down the missile mid-air, before it can do any damage.
And who do we have to thank for that protection? The IDF. The men and women in the Israeli Army who are working day and night to protect millions of innocent civilians from terrorist attacks, It has recently come to my attention that our brave soldiers could use our help.


What We Need & What You Get

Soldiers on the Gaza border have asked for supplies. They are DESPERATELY in need of socks, underwear, towels and other basic supplies.

You get the satisfaction of having provided basic supplies to the brave soldiers who are defending Israel today!

July 13th 2014:

Josh Hasten reports:

100+ reserve soldiers stationed near Gaza of the 360th tank Battalion of the IDF can't thank you enough. I had the honor and privilege of purchasing and delivering not only underwear, socks, and towels, but also – coffee, toothpaste, toothbrushes, shampoo, and other items which they need while they are down there protecting us. Also all items were bought in Sderot, thus supporting local businesses down there. The people of Sderot are grateful! But this is just the beginning!

    The Impact

    This project gives you a unique opportunity to give directly to our soldiers.  Every penny will go directly to purchasing the neccessay supplies for the Israel soldiers. I will make sure that these items are delivered directly to our soldiers on the front lines.

story:
About Us

Greetings Art Lovers! We are The Compound Gallery and Studios located in Oakland, CA. We think art is essential.  We want to continue serving the art community through empowering studio spaces and art making equipment.

The Compound is a place where artists can go to have the resources and community that are available at art institutions.  We are a place that fosters community while providing artists with an abundance of resources and equipment to produce artwork without limitations.  We are a place for art collectors to purchase art.  We are a neighborhood resource for art.  We are a place to take workshops and learn new skills.  We love art, artists, creativity, and making dreams a reality!

Our current building in Oakland, CA.

We are planning to expand into the adjacent building and create The Compound Institute of Fabrefaction (Fabrefaction=17th century word for the “making of art”). This new building will become our 3D building and focus on sculptural arts, while our current building will focus on 2D arts. We will move our current woodshop, metalshop, and ceramic area into the new space and ultimately, expand on our ceramic equipment, start a new artist residency just for ceramics, and acquire a 3d printer, and laser cutter. But we need your help.

We need to raise at least $10,000 to cover the cost of making the building façade pretty (it is pretty hideous now), building out the interior, and hopefully expanding our arsenal of equipment available to artists (if we meet our stretch goals). We also want to be able to provide a free artist residency for ceramic artists. 

We are asking our wonderful patrons, artists,collectors, and community for contributions. If you have ever come to one of our exhibitions, watched a free movie, like having us in your neighborhood, or just want to support the arts, please donate and help us grow. In exchange, we're offering amazing ephemera, original art, workshops, and art vacations! Your contribution will help us make a wonderful space for artists to work, a new space for a 3D artist residency, more workshops,  exhibition space, and a place for the community to go and enjoy art!

We can’t Thank YOU enough!

Our new 3D building needs help!

What We Need

  • $10,000 Initial Bare Bones Cost: Facade improvement (signs, plants, clean up, rent giant dumpster, paint), building construction, lighting, interior, locks, network/IT, etc. We would do the work ourselves.
  • $15,000 Upgrade Cost: more ceramic equipment, common area beautification, fixtures, better facade...
  • $20,000 Stretch Goal Cost: 3d printer, laser cutter, other equipment
  • $25,000 and up: woodshop and metalshop upgrades, electrical upgrades, and more!

Our goal is to start work in mid/late August and be up and running by the end of September.

What You Get

We are so fortunate to be working with so many great artists and can offer you some superb deals on delightful goods. Every person who donates at least $5 will get a ticket to our private THANK YOU party for our campaign supporters. At the party there will be lots of art making, fun, and giveaways! We have so many FANTASTIC perks because ... well, you deserve it!  We will strive to have all the perks ready to ship by the end of the campaign in August. Workshops can be redeemed fairly quickly as we will schedule workshops as the demand grows. Stays at the Hampton Art Manor can be scheduled on our website at HamptonArtManor.com (we are booked through August).

Scroll down this page to see photos of these perks:

  • Bandanas, thank you cards, prints
  • Various workshops
  • Fantastic original art
  • Art retreats - Stay at the Hampton Art Manor and take a series of workshops.


The Impact

Over the past 6 years we have been working tirelessly to build The Compound Gallery into a unique facility that supports both artists and collectors in a professional yet vibrant setting. We love our neighborhood so much and have developed a reputation as a notable local arts community. In the past 6 years we have:

  • Created a place for artists showcase their work and the public can actually view it (yup, we have hours & are open 35 hours a week!)
  • Provided several open call exhibitions for local artists with no entry fee.
  • Gained a reputation as a place for collectors to buy quality art.
  • Maintained a place for our community to come and view art, watch art movies,  see demos, and have fun!
  • Every year we offer 4 artists an Interdisciplinary Artist Residency with FREE 24/7 access to facilities for 6 months.
  • We hold super affordable workshops for the community.
  • Started Art in a Box and have sent out over 3,500 pieces of original Bay Area art to art collectors all over the world!
  • Empowered artists with community and facilities.
  • Dedicated ourselves to the arts because we believe in the importance of art and artists!


Risks & Challenges

There are usually unexpected costs that manifest when building out a space (is there enough power? What is under that drop ceiling? will the equipment fit through the door?) but we are confident we can overcome any hurdle that will come our way. With the help of our community, we are certain to prevail!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but you want to help in other ways, you can:

  • Help us with your brute strength and physical labor by helping us paint, garden, build, etc.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools and help spread the word! 
  • Do you have a piece of equipment you would like to donate?

And there you have it! THANK YOU! THANK YOU! THANK YOU! See our awesome perks below:
story_txt:
About Us
Greetings Art Lovers! We are The Compound Gallery and Studios located in Oakland, CA. We think art is essential.  We want to continue serving the art community through empowering studio spaces and art making equipment. The Compound is a place where artists can go to have the resources and community that are available at art institutions.  We are a place that fosters community while providing artists with an abundance of resources and equipment to produce artwork without limitations.  We are a place for art collectors to purchase art.  We are a neighborhood resource for art.  We are a place to take workshops and learn new skills.  We love art, artists, creativity, and making dreams a reality! Our current building in Oakland, CA.
We are planning to expand into the adjacent building and create The Compound Institute of Fabrefaction (Fabrefaction=17th century word for the “making of art”). This new building will become our 3D building and focus on sculptural arts, while our current building will focus on 2D arts. We will move our current woodshop, metalshop, and ceramic area into the new space and ultimately, expand on our ceramic equipment, start a new artist residency just for ceramics, and acquire a 3d printer, and laser cutter. But we need your help.
We need to raise at least $10,000 to cover the cost of making the building façade pretty (it is pretty hideous now), building out the interior, and hopefully expanding our arsenal of equipment available to artists (if we meet our stretch goals). We also want to be able to provide a free artist residency for ceramic artists. 
We are asking our wonderful patrons, artists,collectors, and community for contributions. If you have ever come to one of our exhibitions, watched a free movie, like having us in your neighborhood, or just want to support the arts, please donate and help us grow. In exchange, we're offering amazing
ephemera, original art, workshops, and art vacations! Your contribution will
help us make a wonderful space for artists to work, a new space for a 3D artist residency, more workshops,  exhibition space, and a place for the community to go and enjoy art!

story:
Please join us in this opportunity to preserve and present Polish heritage in the 21st century.

The Polish Panorama has  educated and entertained audiences, both young and old, for over thirty years.  It dramatizes the history of Poland from the earliest legends to the rise of Pope John Paul II. The 106 characters are drawn from the struggles of writers, peasants, saints, statesman, soldiers, and artists to remain faithful to the ideals of Christianity and the Polish nation.

The Panorama was created under the direction of Msgr. Zdzisław Peszkowski and designed and executed by architect Zbigniew Baran.  Mr. Baran has returned to campus to guide us in the renovation and upgrade of the Polish Panorama.

Working with the head conservator at the Henry Ford Museum, the figures are being evaluated, cleaned, and repaired (as needed). 

 

Click to launch the WXYZ footage: See the Polish Panorama in action! 

 $10.00 Listing in the booklet The History of the Polish Panorama and a Thank You Panorama postcard sent to the U.S. address of your choice.

 $25.00 All of the above and a copy of the booklet

 $50.00 All of the above and an 8x10 photo of Poland by Polish Mission
Director Marcin Chumiecki.

$75.00 All of the above and a CD with images and soundtrack.
$100.00 All of the above and an 11X14 image of the Panorama.

$500.00 Become a Guardian Angel! Your name will be added to the base of one of the figures and you will receive all of the above perks.

$1,000.00  You will become a Guardian Angel and have a private showing of the Panorama for you and 10 guests. Polish refreshments served.

story:
The long, sad story...

My mom, Kristine Cammisa, had purchased a used 1994 Buick LaSabre from her mechanic back in 2004 and the car is about 20 years old now. We did our best to keep it well-maintained despite the struggles we faced living on her small disability income. In 2006 my mom was diagnosed with stage 4 lung cancer after having beaten breast cancer 8 years prior. In 2008 I graduated from college and immediately came home to care for her, but unfortunately the cancer had spread to her brain and the treatments were no longer effective. I kept her home and tried to keep her comfortable until the day she passed away on June 11, 2009. She was my only true family, my best friend and my rolemodel. When she died I was completely devestated and I still suffer post traumatic stress from seeing her slowly deteriorate and finally pass on.

My mom and I at my college graduation.

My 1994 Buick LaSabre.

A day or two after she passed, the HUD Saratoga Springs Housing Authority told me I had to move out of the apartment by June 30th so they could rent the unit to another family. I had less than two weeks to get out and no time to grieve or really process what was happening at the time. I had to give up my two cats and my dog, give away most of my mom's things, and move into another HUD apartment complex for elderly and disabled individuals. I had very little money to live on as well as my mom's funeral bill and other expenses looming over me. I barely managed to survive on $250 a month along with foodstamps and medicaid. I was only 23 when that all happened and I had to grow up very quickly and learn to survive on my own. I have been struggling with poverty ever since, seemingly unable to work my way up or pull myself out of its maw despite having a college degree and plenty of ambition to work. I have worked several minimum wage jobs just to pay my rent, car insurance, gas, phone and internet which are all necessities. I currently work for an HVAC company and only make $420 a month plus commission, but after I pay my bills I am left with $33 to live on. It's just enough to pay my rent and bills, but nothing more. The only way I manage to get by is by doing freelance art on the side, but it is a very inconsistent and unreliable income. I've made very little from freelancing thus far despite all my efforts to get my work out there and market myself.


My cats Babette, Ginseng, and my dog Okie Dokie. All were adopted to new homes.

Over these past three years my decrepit car has cost me nearly $4,000 in repairs/maintenance and it has over 93,000 miles on it now. Everytime I make a little money to save, the car breaks down and wipes out my bank account, putting me right back where I started. I have replaced the entire exhaust system, the ignition control module, the brakes and struts, the tires, the harmonic balancer, the spark plugs, the wiper blades, and just recently I laid out $416.00 to fix the ignition control module AGAIN because the car has been shutting off on me in the middle of driving and stalling frequently. I also have to fix the compressor because if I don't the belt will break and it will wreck the engine, I was told, and I won't have defrosting or defogging in rainy weather or in the winter which is also dangerous. I can't turn on the heat or AC because it smokes and burns. It's rattling so bad right now I feel it in the gas pedal and it's frightening to drive it like that, but I have no choice. Reparing the compressor is going to cost me another $300.00+. Ultimately I will have spent a total of $902.53 fixing my car.

I fear the old Buick is finally on its way out and I desperately need a car to get to work, doctor's appointments, and to do my grocery shopping. The public transportation in my town is pitiful at best; the CDTA buses don't go anywhere near my job and the taxis charge $8.00 per ride which would devour most of my income, leaving me unable to pay my rent and bills. My car is my lifeline, I don't know how I can get by up here without it.

What your donations will be used for:

I am hoping to buy another used car from the years 2000-2006 in the price range of $3,000-$6,000. My car is still worth about $1,000 and if I can sell it or trade it in that would help. Any donations towards getting a newer used car would be greatly appreciated and you will help me stay afloat. If I cannot get to work, I'll lose my job and be back at the bottom of the barrel, teetering on homelessness. I don't ever want to be in that position again!

The many perks of donating:

Each level of donations made will be rewarded with my artwork, be it prints, originals, or commissioned pieces. I do not expect to get anything for free or simply take handouts. Every contributor will get something nice in return as well as my deep gratitude. I'm a hard worker and passionate about making a living as a freelance artist. By donating to this cause you will not only help me reach my goal in obtaining a reliable vehicle, you will be helping me in my career as an artist too! Money I don't have to shell out to fix a dying car can be used to produce artbooks and fund my business.

The perks will be done on a first come, first serve basis. I cannot give set dates for when each contributor will recieve their perk because it depends on what they get based on how much they donated. Making art is time-consuming and it varies from project to project. If I make even $1,000 you can bet I am going to be swamped in commissions, so it may take me a few months to finish everything for everyone. For anything that needs to be shipped I will mail out perks on Monday mornings. I can't take multiple trips to the post office with my car the way it is, so that's how it will be. I appreciate your understanding and patience if you are waiting for your perk!

After you donate please e-mail me: emilycammisa@gmail.com and describe what you would like me to draw for you if your perk involves art commission work. For some commissions you will have to e-mail me reference pictures or photographs. Please be as detailed as possible with what you want. If you are unsure, you can also leave it to me to create whatever I want and just let me surprise you! :) For fine art prints, please link me to the image(s) from my DeviantArt gallery that you would like to have a print of. The same goes for art stickers. I have a sticker maker and I can make stickers of anything you want from my gallery up to 5 inches wide.

To get a feel for my artistic ability and the kind of work I produce, please have look below:

DeviantArt: http://otaku-no-bijutsu.deviantart.com/

Portfolio: http://emilycammisa.daportfolio.com/

Personal website: http://www.emilycammisa.com/

Tumblr: http://otaku1811.tumblr.com/

Thank you so much for reading this and I hope you decide to contribute. I will do my best to give you quality artwork and make it worth your while :)

story:
Who we are

The Joseph Boshier Collective is a collaboration between film makers, Ivano Darra,  and Walter Reed and artist Lesley Hilling.  We are putting on an exhibition at the Standpoint gallery in November presenting the life and times of modernist architect and outsider artist, Joseph Boshier.  The show will include a twenty minute documentary film about Boshier.
We are using architect and outsider artist, Joseph Boshier as a device to explore the changing face of our cities.  Our project also probes outsider art investigating marginalised artists who are driven to produce masses of work with little or no care for the commercial art world.

The Enigmatic World of Joseph Boshier

'Fiction enables us to grasp reality and at the same time that which is veiled by reality'  Marcel Broodthaars
On Wednesday September 29th 1948 the first two floors of Chesney Court buckled and the ten storey concrete structure collapsed leaving three dead and forty seven injured. Ten years earlier the building was proclaimed as a breakthrough in design and construction, the collapse of the building shook the architectural world and the public at large. Although the subsequent inquiry could find no obvious reason for the disaster, the press singled out the architect, Joseph Boshier for blame. Boshier had a love hate relationship with the press, due partly to his brief involvement with fascism. He had been a successful London architect with several small but impressive projects behind him - now his career was in ruins.
After a nervous breakdown and estrangement from his wife and child Joseph became a virtual recluse. He disappeared from the architectural scene and was forgotten.

On his death in 1982 his south London home revealed a staggering trove of intricate wooden sculptures and a mass of drawings and writings. Labyrinthine, oppressive, dark, narrow and magical, his home was stuffed full of collected artifacts and ephemera. The once revered and public figure had retreated into a self imposed exile, solidifying his existence in his small terraced house in Camberwell.
Subsisting for decades on a tiny income, he had produced a series of extraordinary sculptures, collaging new forms out of salvaged wood - often using his own floorboards and furniture and re-working them with an obsessive joinery. These works are the key to uncovering the real Joseph Boshier.
The collective has ascertained the whereabouts of most of Boshier's work and this will be displayed along with other evidence of his existence, like his prolific diaries and ephemera from his workshop.
Boshier may or may not have existed. This is for the public to decide.

The exhibition

The exhibition at the Standpoint gallery www.standpointlondon.co.uk in November will show many of Boshier's wooden artifacts from his small wall pieces to his large standing towers.  The show will also include documents and photographs from his life as an architect, his prolific diaries and ephemera from his home.
There will also be a twenty minute documentary that traces the life of Boshier, called 'The Uncovering of Joseph Boshier'.
The exhibition will spill over into Shoreditch library where a display will focus on the ideals and politics behind architecture and housing between and just after WW2.
We will  be inviting young people from Hackney Community College and the Shoreditch Trust to come to the gallery for several artist led talks:  why we came up with the idea of the Boshier project: how we got it to work and where we intend to take it in the future.  
Artist, Hilling will explain how the work has been assembled and the ideas behind it.  Film makers Darra and Reed will talk about creating a small film - writing a script, casting, finding locations, filming and editing.  We are also inviting people from other professions to talk about 'the idea', because that's what Joseph Boshier is, an idea.  How engineers, architects, designers, photographers get ideas and then manage to take them further.  We want, above all to enthuse the young people that come to the show and talks.

The documentary film

Similar to “Arena” and  “The Southbank Show” and BBC4 documentaries fronted by young academics, it features the voice and archive films of Boshier's daughter, Constance Ripley who, sadly, is now deceased.  In 1983 she gave an interview on Radio London talking candidly about the discovery of a father whom she had believed dead for most of her life.
Dr Derval Tubridy takes the role of cultural commentator and friend of Boshier.
Turbridy is a Senior Lecturer in English Literature and Visual Culture at Goldsmith’s college. She introduces Joseph, narrates his story with the help of other people who knew Joseph and experts on architecture, housing and outsider art.
For more information about the film and to see a trailer: http://www.josephboshier.co.uk/documentary.html

Sponsorship

We need funding to make this happen.  We have already raised some of our goal from fundraising events we've organised, like a sponsored walk that took in the sites of south London specific to Boshier's life, a pop up shop selling Boshier ephemera and a film night.  And several business' have invested in kind.  We now need one thousand pounds to fully finance our event.
If you choose to sponsor us we will use the money for:
  • publicity
  • hire of display cases
  • insurance
  • transport costs
  • payment for actors and the director of photography
  • the library display

Your rewards

A £5 pledge

Invite to Private view and Joseph Boshier booklet signed by curator and film makers.

A £10 pledge

A big thank you on the film credits and on the wall of the gallery. An invite to the private view and all talks to be held.

A £25 pledge

A special limited edition of our documentary, signed by the artist and film makers, and a special mention in the credits. And invite to Private view.

A £100 pledge

Featuring in our documentary film. At the end we have a selection of curators, architects and artists talking about the work - be one of them! A big thank you on the film credits and on the wall of the gallery. An invite to the private view and all talks to be held where you will be introduced as someone who helped the project happen.

A £150 pledge (for business's)

Your logo on our flyers, advertising and posters and booklet and in our film credits.  With a suitable thank you, sponsored by etc.  The publicity will be seen by thousands of people.

A £300 pledge

An authenticated piece of Joseph Boshier's art work, for collection after the show.  We have three pieces available - please email for pictures, size etc.  You can also arrange a private viewing.

We've added some more down to earth perks - a ten pound pledge could get you a bottle of organic Elderberry wine, one of Joseph's favourite tipples!
There is also a limited number of Cucumber Relish and Chilli Jams - so check out the perks!
story_txt:
Who we are
The Joseph Boshier Collective is a collaboration between film makers, Ivano Darra,  and Walter Reed and artist Lesley Hilling.  We are putting on an exhibition at the Standpoint gallery in November presenting the life and times of modernist architect and outsider artist, Joseph Boshier.  The show will include a twenty minute documentary film about Boshier.We are using architect and outsider artist, Joseph Boshier as a device to explore the changing face of our cities.  Our project also probes outsider art investigating marginalised artists who are driven to produce masses of work with little or no care for the commercial art world.

The Enigmatic World of Joseph Boshier
'Fiction enables us to grasp reality and at the same time that which is veiled by reality'  Marcel Broodthaars
On Wednesday September 29th 1948 the first two floors of Chesney Court buckled and the ten storey concrete structure collapsed leaving three dead and forty seven injured. Ten years earlier the building was proclaimed as a breakthrough in design and construction, the collapse of the building shook the architectural world and the public at large. Although the subsequent inquiry could find no obvious reason for the disaster, the press singled out the architect, Joseph Boshier for blame. Boshier had a love hate relationship with the press, due partly to his brief involvement with fascism. He had been a successful London architect with several small but impressive projects behind him - now his career was in ruins. After a nervous breakdown and estrangement from his wife and child Joseph became a virtual recluse. He disappeared from the architectural scene and was forgotten. On his death in 1982 his south London home revealed a staggering trove of intricate wooden sculptures and a mass of drawings and writings. Labyrinthine, oppressive, dark, narrow and magical, his home was stuffed full of collected artifacts and ephemera. The once revered and public figure had retreated into a self imposed exile, solidifying his existence in his small terraced house in Camberwell. Subsisting for decades on a tiny income, he had produced a series of extraordinary sculptures, collaging new forms out of salvaged wood - often using his own floorboards and furniture and re-working them with an obsessive joinery. These works are the key to uncovering the real Joseph Boshier.The collective has ascertained the whereabouts of most of Boshier's work and this will be displayed along with other evidence of his existence, like his prolific diaries and ephemera from his workshop.Boshier may or may not have existed. This is for the public to decide.

The exhibition
The exhibition at the Standpoint gallery www.standpointlondon.co.uk in November will show many of Boshier's wooden artifacts from his small wall pieces to his large standing towers.  The show will also include documents and photographs from his life as an architect, his prolific diaries and ephemera from his home. There will also be a twenty minute documentary that traces the life of Boshier, called 'The Uncovering of Joseph Boshier'.
The exhibition will spill over into Shoreditch library where a display will focus on the ideals and politics behind architecture and housing between and just after WW2.We will  be inviting young people from Hackney Community College and the Shoreditch Trust to come to the gallery for several artist led talks:  why we came up with the idea of the Boshier project: how we got it to work and where we intend to take it in the future.  Artist, Hilling will explain how the work has been assembled and the ideas behind it.  Film makers Darra and Reed will talk about creating a small film - writing a script, casting, finding locations, filming and editing.  We are also inviting people from other professions to talk about 'the idea', because that's what Joseph Boshier is, an idea.  How engineers, architects, designers, photographers get ideas and then manage to take them further.  We want, above all to enthuse the young people that come to the show and talks.

The documentary film
Similar to “Arena” and  “The Southbank Show” and BBC4 documentaries fronted by young academics, it features the voice and archive films of Boshier's daughter, Constance Ripley who, sadly, is now deceased.  In 1983 she gave an interview on Radio London talking candidly about the discovery of a father whom she had believed dead for most of her life. Dr Derval Tubridy takes the role of cultural commentator and friend of Boshier. Turbridy is a Senior Lecturer in English Literature and Visual Culture at Goldsmith’s college. She introduces Joseph, narrates his story with the help of other people who knew Joseph and experts on architecture, housing and outsider art.
For more information about the film and to see a trailer: http://www.josephboshier.co.uk/documentary.html


Sponsorship
We need funding to make this happen.  We have already raised some of our goal from fundraising events we've organised, like a sponsored walk that took in the sites of south London specific to Boshier's life, a pop up shop selling Boshier ephemera and a film night.  And several business' have invested in kind.  We now need one thousand pounds to fully finance our event.
If you choose to sponsor us we will use the money for:


publicity
hire of display cases
insurance
transport costs
payment for actors and the director of photography
the library display

Your rewards
A £5 pledge
Invite to Private view and Joseph Boshier booklet signed by curator and film makers.
A £10 pledge
A big thank you on the film credits and on the wall of the gallery. An invite to the private view and all talks to be held.
A £25 pledge
A special limited edition of our documentary, signed by the artist and film makers, and a special mention in the credits. And invite to Private view.
A £100 pledge
Featuring in our documentary film. At the end we have a selection of curators, architects and artists talking about the work - be one of them! A big thank you on the film credits and on the wall of the gallery. An invite to the private view and all talks to be held where you will be introduced as someone who helped the project happen.
A £150 pledge (for business's)
Your logo on our flyers, advertising and posters and booklet and in our film credits.  With a suitable thank you, sponsored by etc.  The publicity will be seen by thousands of people.
A £300 pledge
An authenticated piece of Joseph Boshier's art work, for collection after the show.  We have three pieces available - please email for pictures, size etc.  You can also arrange a private viewing.
We've added some more down to earth perks - a ten pound pledge could get you a bottle of organic Elderberry wine, one of Joseph's favourite tipples! There is also a limited number of Cucumber Relish and Chilli Jams - so check out the perks!

story:
Artist Residency at Babayan Culture House

 

Hello—I was recently selected to be an artist-in-residence this September at Babayan Culture House in Cappadocia, Turkey! I am thrilled to have the opportunity to focus on textiles and photography while living in this surreal cavernous environment. I am especially looking forward to learning from the local artisans within the village, ensuring this cultural exchange will have a profound and lasting effect on my creative practice.

 

                

                

                

 

                

                 Examples of woven jewelry

 

My strong interest in fiber arts originated while traveling through the Sacred Valley region of Peru. I was instantly awestruck by the array of vibrant woven textiles, and I returned to New York determined to learn how to weave. I have since been working on my technique for two years, focusing on small textile pieces that can be worn as jewelry. This residency will afford me time and resources to continue developing my pieces, specifically in experimenting with natural fiber dyeing and implementing new textures and patterns in my designs. I am excited to see how these new surroundings and culture will influence what I think is possible. Although I will center most of my work on weaving, my photographic nature will not allow me to keep the camera down! Accordingly, I will be photographing a series inspired by Cappadocia’s extraordinary atmosphere.

 

                

                 Cappadocia's surreal stone formations

 

Weaving is especially important to me because I feel I am carrying on a piece of my family’s heritage. Throughout my childhood my grandmother introduced me to a wide range of art projects, sharing with me the importance of individual expression through craft. It wasn’t until I returned from Peru that I learned she had been an avid weaver. I like to think my grandmother would be pleased with my textile pieces. And although she and I never had the chance to weave together, her unique tapestries hanging on my wall inspire me to be free and experimental in what I create.

 

                 

                   My grandmother at her loom

 

This residency is an incredible opportunity to merge my creative ideas with new influences, and I am honored to be able to take part in such an experience. Having the support of family and friends (and strangers!) is invaluable, and I am so grateful to all who contribute to and share my project.

 

Your Contribution

Your generous contributions will go towards the following:

  • Travel/airfare
  • Residency fee
  • Meals
  • Visa
  • Travel Health Insurance
  • Film + developing
  • Fibers, dyes + weaving supplies

Note: Any extra funding will go towards shipping items back to U.S. and to luggage fees.

 

                                     

 

In Return

No matter how big or small, each contribution is greatly appreciated. To show my deepest gratitude you will receive a photographic print from my series shot in Cappadocia or a piece of handwoven jewelry—or both!—depending on the level you choose. I am excited to share what I've been working on with this community of supporters.

 

                  

 

Impact

Taking part in an artist residency has been a longtime goal of mine, and I can’t think of a better place to be inspired and expand on my work than in Cappadocia’s uniquely compelling environment. I look forward to interacting with other international artists-in-residence, sharing our projects and receiving feedback from different points of view. I hope through this artistic exchange and immersion in the local culture I may share insight into my culture as well.


I strongly believe that crowdfunding is a great way to support important projects and receive unique thank-yous in return, and each month I will make a donation to help support others’ goals through Indiegogo. It helps keep the cycle of support flowing.


                 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that many may not be able to support with monetary contributions, but you can still help by spreading the word about my project and sharing this link with family and friends through email or Facebook!
 
 

Gratitude

I am beyond thankful to all my family and friends who share my enthusiasm for this opportunity; your support goes a long way. And to all who contribute to this project and spread the word, I deeply appreciate all you have done to make this dream a reality! Thank you.

 
                   
 
 

Links

Photographic portfolio - www.summerm.com

Undeforestation Project - www.undeforestation.org

story:
Hello, my name is Krystal Jolicoeur! I am a senior Fiber Major at the Kansas City Art Institute, and I have recently been offered the opportunity to spend a semester abroad studying at the University of Tasmania. As a mixed media textile artist, this experience will be a priceless addition to my academic and artistic growth. Exploring the impact of social constructs on traditional societies through the study of displacement, assimilation, and conquering of adversity is how I seek to find comprehension of self in my artwork. The exploration of traditional cultures fuels my work, and finding my relation to others is the outcome.

After a brief art history lecture on the plight that was the modern day aborigine, I began to research them as peoples. I found that my displacement from Haiti to the U.S. as a child was the strength within my art; this paralleled the displacement of the aborigine people, which only illuminated the strength they had within their beliefs. My forced assimilation back into a family structure that I did not understand mirrored their forced assimilation into white contemporary Australia, which, in many ways, taught them that understanding one another's differences was most important. Understanding each other and our differences is what strengthens us as a society. When I was a young child, my grandmother used to say to me: "Bay kou, blye; pote mak, sonje." [You] give a blow, [and you] forget; [yet if you] bear [the] scars, [you will] remember.

These words resonated within me when I realized that we were in the position of those who bore the marks. Understanding came with the mark bearing, and it was essential to our forgiveness and transcendence. Those who were on the other side of the spectrum did not have those experiences, and therefore did not have that understanding. The impact of social constructs on traditional societies became the basis of my fiber art and has developed into the concept of my senior thesis.

 

I am requesting monetary support that will allow me to embark on this journey. The funds for this project will cover the plane ticket and room and board. All donors will receive a hand written letter of thanks and an original work of art from yours truly. If you cannot donate, please consider sharing this link to spread the word. Every little bit helps!

Thank you for your time! ~Krystal

story:
Fontaine Playing Cards - finally available, with your help.

On October 10th I posted a Youtube video for a card magic effect of mine titled Marbles - in this video I used a deck of cards that had not been seen before. Simple, minimalistic, and streamlined. The deck did not have a title, nor did anyone know where it had come from, or who made it. This is where the intrigue began.

My name is Zach Mueller - I am a young old magician and sleight of hand nerd from Los Angeles, and this was simply a back design that I put together one night in photoshop - I used two letter 'F's in the same font as my first card magic release, 'Fontaine'. I wanted the design to resemble Wynn Casino Playing Cards and Jerry's Nugget Playing Cards, with a hint of Fontaine for fun.

I had a prototype deck made, used it in a video, and the intrigue ensued. I kept posting videos, using these cards, but offering no information about them. I didn't want people to lose the mystery that surrounded this deck.

Hundreds of comments, tweets, facebook messages asking, "Where did you get the that deck??". These commenters saw that the font on the cards was the same as in my effect 'Fontaine', and they named it themselves. The Fontaine Deck.

Two months ago I decided that if all these people wanted the deck, they would never stop asking. It was time to take this from a fun prototype deck I had made for my own enjoyment, to a real, full fledged product that people could actually own for themselves.

In those two months, the Fontaines now have a custom ace of spades, jokers, ad card, seal, and even a custom box with a utility device for magicians built into the design. I've pimped out the prototype you see in the trailer above as much as I can - I'm only one step away from making this deck of cards a reality. I need your help to do that.

The Deck Itself

The Fontaines started with just a back design. Now, every deck will come with the following:

  • The Stock & Finish - printed on classic bicycle stock with linen finish, perfect for cardists and magicians alike.

  • The Ace of Spaces - simple, streamlined and elegant. Featuring the fontaine box logo running through the center of the Spade.

  • The Jokers - also sporting the box logo with the fontaine F for pips.

  • The Ad card - fontaine box logo in the center, text which reads 1 of 2500 and first edition.

  • The Blank Facer - a card for magicians, to use in various effects including an upcoming Wire release.

  • The Seal -  not shown in the trailer or product shots, but the vector art of the seal can be found in the gallery.

  • The Box - with a utility device for magicians built into the design. My friend Michael Stern and I developed a concept called the Vintage holdout 4 years ago that is a slight alteration you make to a card box that opens the doors to TONS of amazing tricks - the downside is only works with these Vintage Series bicycle decks. Until now. I built the same method right into the box design.

The Goal

Starting today - right now - you can purchase the Fontaine deck. Only 2500 Red Fontaine decks will be made - ever. This is your chance to get your hands one a deck, a pair, a brick, an uncut sheet and many more unique perks all listed to the right.

We need to reach our goal of $10,000 to make these decks a reality. This a fixed funding campaign, meaning if you purchase any of our perks and we don't reach our goal of $10,000 within 30 days - you will get your money back.

The Pricing

Every perk on the campaign includes free shipping within the USA, so if that $12 price tag on one deck scares you, realize that it's going to cost me anywhere from $3-5 to ship that one deck in an envelope to your doorstep. And also the price of the envelope. So that's included if you live in the USA. 

If you're thinking $12 bucks even with shipping is still a lot, I agree. The more decks you buy, the cheaper the price, so get your costco mentality and buy in bulk. Or don't. It's really up to you.

International Shipping 

IMPORTANT: If you live outside the USA you MUST add $8.00 at checkout, or I won't be able to ship out your decks. I know, international shipping sucks. Sorry guys.

story:
-What-
This spring, the Institute for Psychogeographic Adventure brings its one-of-a-kind solo experience to the historic Brooklyn neighborhood with EXPERIMENT #17 (DUMBO).  Individuals (or pairs) sign up for a personalized journey that remixes history, memory, the everyday and the spectacular. A multitude of performers will be scattered through the neighborhood to lead you through a series of unexpected and fabulous DUMBO encounters. When’s the last time you stopped to smell the pastrami? JOIN THE ADVENTURE.

-Where/When-
Performances will take place by appointment only on May 4th and 5th, 2013 between the hours of noon and 5pm in locations across DUMBO, Brooklyn.

-Who-
The Institute for Psychogeographic Adventure (IPA) is a team of interdisciplinary artists who explore the intersection of place and performance. We create unique site-specific performance experiences in response to local history, neighborhoods, and the urban landscape. The IPA is Andrew Goldberg, Liza Wade Green, Radoslaw Konopka, and Emily Rea; 2013 MFA Candidates in Brooklyn College’s Performance and Interactive Media Arts program.

-Our Goal-
The IPA’s goal is to raise at least $5000.

Your donations will go towards:

- renting performance and rehearsal spaces

- hiring performers and technicians

- paying for materials and costumes

- publicity and marketing

-More ways to help-

- Help us spread the word about our campaign and project. Please share our IndieGoGo campaign with your friends and colleagues.

- Visit and like our facebook page here: https://www.facebook.com/TheInstituteForPsychogeographicAdventure?fref=ts

- Follow us on Twitter here:
https://twitter.com/InstPsychAdv

For more information on this project visit our website: www.ipaexperiments.com

Thank you for your support.

JOIN THE ADVENTURE.
